field_edited_text.value:
164 CHESAPEAKE BAY BRIDGE

the foundations conditions at the site of the main channel span near Tol-
chester.

(7) Coverdale and Colpitts, Consulting Engineers of New York, have
estimated that it will cost $96,000 per annum to operate, maintain and
provide necessary insurance for a bridge at either of the two sites, and the
Traffic Report prepared by these engineers shows that the gross earnings for
the average of the first five years of operation, beginning with 1941, based
on a toll schedule of $1.00 per passenger car and driver and $.20 for addi-
tional passengers, amounts to $762,000 and $875,000 for the Millers Island
and Sandy Point sites respectively. The above earnings are based on the:
assumption that a bridge at either of the two sites is to be considered as an
independent unit and on the assumption that none of the other crossings
in Maryland’s Primary Bridge Program is to be constructed. When a
bridge at either of these sites is considered as combined with the three
bridges in the North-South Highway, the above amounts are estimated to
be changed to $781,000 and $885,000, respectively. It therefore appears
that the earnings of a bridge at the Sandy Point-Kent Island Site will
exceed the earnings at the Millers Island-Tolchester Site by at least
$104,000 per annum.

A bridge at the Sandy Point Site can be constructed in two and one-half
years after the construction is started, and the Progress Chart presented
herewith shows the sequence of construction operations beginning in January
1939 and ending in June, 1941, at which time a bridge at this site can be
opened to traffic. ‘

(8) The War Department Engineers have indicated that the approval of
plans for a bridge between Millers Island and Tolchester will not be further
considered at this time. It therefore appears that a bridge could not be
constructed at the Millers Island Site at this time, even if its cost and
earnings had indicated a higher rate of return on the investment than a
bridge between Sandy Point and Kent Island. The results of the engineering
work leading to the preparation of this report have shown clearly that a
bridge across the Chesapeake Bay between Sandy Point and Kent Island
1s feasible from an engineering standpoint, that it is practicable from the
standpoint of providing adequate navigation clearances, that it will be
approved by the War Department, that its cost is reasonable, and that its
estimated prospective revenues from tolls represent a higher rate of return
on the investment than is represented by the tolls from the bridge at Millers
Island. :
